com.tealium.mobile.android
Class TealiumTagger

java.lang.Object
  com.tealium.mobile.android.TealiumTagger

public final class TealiumTagger
extends java.lang.Object

Version 1.2

Introduction

This library provides Tealium customers the means to tag their native Android applications for the purpose of leveraging the vendor-neutral tag management platform offered by Tealium.

It provides:

  • web-analytics integration via the Tealium platform
  • Android view (activity) tracking, similar to traditional web page tracking, utilizing your favorite analytics vendor. The name of the activity will be used as the 'page name'
  • intelligent network-sensitive caching
  • custom action tracking
  • implemented with the user in mind. All tracking calls are asynchronous as to not interfere or degrade the user experience.

Tealium Requirements

Ensure an active Tealium account exists. You will need the following items:

  • Your Tealium Account Id (it will likely be your company name)
  • The Tealium Profile name to be associated with the app (your account may have several profiles, ideally one of them is dedicated to your Android app)
  • The Tealium environment to use (this will be one of these values: 'prod', 'qa', or 'dev')

Requirements

This Android library requires Android 2.2 (API Level 8) and above.

Installation - Source

If directly compiling source is preferred, simply place this source file into your source path, in the proper package directory.

Installation - Jar Library

If a binary jar file is preferred, get the jar file from the github repo located at github.com/Tealium/android-tagger and include it utilizing your preferred project management strategy (ant, maven, etc).

Installation - Use Permissions

The library requires the following permission be granted in the app manifest file:
  • ACCESS_NETWORK_STATE
  • INTERNET

Usage

An instance of the TealiumTagger must exist *per* Activity. The TealiumTagger instance must be created within the activity's onCreate() lifecycle method, while also calling each of the other lifecycle methods, as followed: 
 
 public void onCreate() {
        //...your custom activity initialization code
 
        //remember, the account and profile's must already exist in Tealium
        this.tealiumTagger = new TealiumTagger(this, "company_name", "android_app_name", "dev");
 }
 
 public void onPause() {
        //...your custom activity pause code
 
        this.tealiumTagger.onPause();
 }
 
 public void onResume() {
        //...your custom activity resume code
 
        this.tealiumTagger.onResume();
 }
 
 public void onDestroy() {
        //...your custom activity destroy code
 
        this.tealiumTagger.onDestroy();
 }

Extended Usage

In addition to the auto-tracking features provided by the lifecycle methods above, the TealiumTagger also exposes two additional methods to be utilized for more fine grained tracking.

Dialog Tracking

One of the two additional methods is trackScreenViewed(). This can be called whenever a sub view is displayed, whether it is a tab page, a dialog (modal or not), etc. An example usage is as followed: 
 
 protected void onPrepareDialog(int id, Dialog dialog) {
                String dialogName = ...//determine the name of this dialog
                super.onPrepareDialog(id, dialog);
                
                this.tealiumTagger.trackScreenViewed(dialogName);
 }

Custom Variables

This API supports passing custom name/value pairs to the utag platform. The Map variables constructor parameter will be set as an internal instance variable, and passed with each subsequent call into the utag platform. You can modify any or all these variables using the setVariables() or setVariable() methods. Additionally, each tracking method allows the caller to override these variables just for the single call.

Item Click Tracking

The next additional method is trackItemClicked(). This can be called any click action occurs, and tracking is desirable. An example usage is as followed: 
 //...
        item.setOnClickListener(new OnClickListener() {
 
                        public void onClick(View v) {
                                //..custom click handling code
                                String itemClickedName = //..determine the name to use for the item
                                this.tealiumTagger.trackItemClicked(itemClickedName);
                        }
                });
 //...

Field Detail

lifecycle

public TealiumLifecycle lifecycle
Constructor Detail

TealiumTagger

public TealiumTagger(Activity activity,
                     java.lang.String account,
                     java.lang.String profile,
                     java.lang.String environment)
An instance of TealiumTagger must be created during the onCreate() method of all activities. Please keep a reference to this tagger instance in your activity, so that it can be used in other lifecycle methods (and to prevent it from being garbage collected). NOTE: the creation of this instance assumes the activity will be displayed, and will invoke a traditional 'page view' request into the utag platform. OPTIONAL: if you wish to delay the initialization sequence for some additional process to complete then use the TealiumTagger(Activity, AccountString, ProfileString, TargetString, Map, ReadyBoolean) method.

Parameters:
activity - - The activity in which this instance is being instantiated
account - - The tealium account name (likely your company name)
profile - - The tealium profile being associated with this android app. Best practice is to create a profile exclusively for this android app.
environment - - must be one of these values: 'dev', 'prod', or 'qa'.

TealiumTagger

public TealiumTagger(Activity activity,
                     java.lang.String account,
                     java.lang.String profile,
                     java.lang.String environment,
                     java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> variables)
This method calls TealiumTagger(Activity, String, String, String) while also allowing a custom set of name/value pairs to be passed with each call into the utag platform.

TealiumTagger

public TealiumTagger(Activity activity,
                     java.lang.String account,
                     java.lang.String profile,
                     java.lang.String environment,
                     java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> variables,
                     boolean ready)
This method calls TealiumTagger(Activity, String, String, String) while also allowing a custom set of name/value pairs to be passed with each call into the utag platform and provides for the optional ready flag for optionally delay the wake sequence (and the default auto track view call) for some other process to complete. If the "ready" argument is "false" then the loadingAutotrackScreenViewReady call MUST be made when the desired data has become available to complete the wake sequence.

Method Detail

setVariables

public void setVariables(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> variables)
This method resets the variables to be passed with each subsequent utag call. NOTE: if it is desirable to pass custom variables to the utag platform with the initial 'page view' occurring at the time of the initial display of the activity's view content, ensure the constructor is passed these variables, since the constructor will initiate an automatic call into the utag platform.

setVariable

public void setVariable(java.lang.String name,
                        java.lang.String value)
This method changes the value of a single variable to be passed with each subsequent utag call. Pass null as the value to remove a name/value pair from the set to be passed to utag.

addVariables

public void addVariables(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> variables)
This method is for adding additional key-value pairs of data to all utag calls from the activity called from.

Parameters:
variables - String Map of data to add

loadingAutotrackScreenViewReady

public void loadingAutotrackScreenViewReady()

onPause

public void onPause()
This method must be called in your activity's onPause() method. Calling this method will allow Tealium to persist the internal request queue for later processing.

onResume

public void onResume()
This method must be called in your activity's onResume() method. Calling this method will allow any queued requests to be loaded and potentially delivered.

onDestroy

public void onDestroy()
This method must be called in your activity's onDestroy() method. Calling this method will ensure all tealium activity ceases and properly cleaned up.

applicationCreate

public void applicationCreate()
This method should only be called once when your application starts, either from your application's onCreate method or your initial activity's onCreate method. All the lifecycle tracking methods (applicationCreate, applicationResume, applicationPause, applicationDestroy) should be called by your application subclass or by your main activity if you application has only one activity. In the event you have multiple activities, these methods may have to be wrapped in methods that first check to see if your application's activities are active or being masked by another application's activities. Note: Successive calls of the same type are automatically suppressed. So, if applicationCreate() is called by multiple methods, only the first call will be accepted until another application lifecycle method is called (applicationResume(), applicationPause(), applicationDestroy()).

applicationResume

public void applicationResume()
Call this method when your application returns to the foreground. Note: Successive applicationResume() calls are automatically suppressed until another application lifecycle call is made.

applicationPause

public void applicationPause()
Call this method when your application goes into the background. Note: Successive applicationPause() calls are automatically suppressed until another application lifecycle call is made.

applicationDestroy

public void applicationDestroy()
Call this method when your application is being destroyed. Note: Successive applicationDestroy() calls are automatically suppressed until another application lifecycle call is made.

trackItemClicked

public void trackItemClicked(java.lang.String itemName)
Use this method if tracking clicks on objects is desirable. Call this method within any click handler code and pass a non-null item name.

Parameters:
itemName - the name of the button, image, layout or other object being clicked

trackItemClicked

public void trackItemClicked(java.lang.String itemName,
                             java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> variables)
This call is similar to trackItemClicked(String) except it allows any custom variables to be passed. NOTE: the variables parameter will be utilized to override those passed into the constructor or the setVariables() method.

Parameters:
itemName - the name of the item to be tracked. This is similar to a 'link' being tracked by traditional web analytics
variables - any set of name/value pairs that need to be passed to the utag platform.

trackScreenViewed

public void trackScreenViewed(java.lang.String viewName)
This method can be used to track the display of sub-screens within a single activity, such as tab content or a dialog. NOTE: do NOT call this method to track the display of the Activity itself, as this is already performed by the lifecycle methods automatically.

Parameters:
viewName - the name of the screen. This is similar to a 'page' in traditional web analytics

trackScreenViewed

public void trackScreenViewed(java.lang.String viewName,
                              java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> variables)
This call is similar to trackScreenViewed(String) except it allows any custom variables to be passed. NOTE: the variables parameter will be utilized to override those passed into the constructor or the setVariables() method.

Parameters:
viewName - the name of the screen. This is similar to a 'page' in traditional web analytics
variables - any set of name/value pairs that need to be passed to the utag platform.

trackCustomEvent

public void trackCustomEvent(java.lang.String eventName,
                             java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> variables)

callback

public void callback()

resetLifecycleLog

public void resetLifecycleLog()
Zeros out lifecycle log data.
